user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 17.8.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
Violation: the function parameter 'str' is declared as 'const char *str'. The expression '*(str++)' uses post-increment on the parameter, which modifies the pointer itself. MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 forbids modifying a pointer parameter (the object it points to may be modified, but not the pointer), so this fragment violates the rule.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/4502.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_has_token_caseless_:
```c
bool
MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (const char *str,
                             const char *const token,
                             size_t token_len)
{
  if (0 == token_len)
    return false;

  while (0 != *str)
  {
    size_t i;
    /* Skip all whitespaces and empty tokens. */
    while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str || ',' == *str)
      str++;

    /* Check for token match. */
    i = 0;
    while (1)
    {
      const char sc = *(str++);
      const char tc = token[i++];

      if (0 == sc)
        return false;
      if (! charsequalcaseless (sc, tc))
        break;
      if (i >= token_len)
      {
        /* Check whether substring match token fully or
         * has additional unmatched chars at tail. */
        while (' ' == *str || '\t' == *str)
          str++;
        /* End of (sub)string? */
        if ((0 == *str) || (',' == *str) )
          return true;
        /* Unmatched chars at end of substring. */
        break;
      }
    }
    /* Find next substring. */
    while (0 != *str && ',' != *str)
      str++;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as MHD_str_has_token_caseless_.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
